sen.j: 在家（ざいけ）とは、住屋及びそれに付属する耕地及び住民のこと。
sen.e: Zaike was a house, and an arable land and residents belonging to the house.
Zaike was a house, and the arable land and residents belonging to the house.
Zaike was a house, and the cultivated land and residents belonging to the house.

sen.j: 荘園・公領における租税（年貢・公事・夫役）収取単位（在家役）としても用いられ、その負担者である住民のみを指す場合もある。
sen.e: It was also used as a unit (Zaikeyaku) for collecting tax (land tax, public duties, labor services) in the shoen (landed estate) or koryo (public lands.)
It was also used as a unit (Zaikeyaku) for collecting taxes (land tax, public duties, labor services) within shoen (landed estates) or koryo (public lands).

sen.j: 中世において成立した収取体制においては、雑役系の公事・夫役は名田を収取単位として租税の賦課が行われていたが、名田が十分に確立されていない地域や供御人・神人など荘園・公領の支配体系に属しない人々（主に非農業民）から公事・夫役を収取するために在家を単位として賦課したのである。
sen.e: Under the tax collection system established in the Medieval era, taxes of public duties and labor services, which were kinds of zoyaku, were assessed for myoden (rice field lots) as a collection unit; on the other hand, taxes of public duties and labor services were collected on the region where myoden had not sufficiently established or from kugonin (group of producer-merchants) or jinin (shrine dependents) who did not belong to the ruling system of shoen and koryo (mainly, non-cultivators) by assessing for zaike as a collection unit.

sen.j: 特に在地領主が名主化して百姓名の成立が進まなかった東国や九州で在家役が多く課されている。
sen.e: Particularly, in Togoku (eastern Japan) and Kyushu where zaichi ryoshu (local proprietor) became nanushi-like (traditional headman) and hyakushomyo (or myoden (name fields)), many Zaikeyaku were levied.

Particularly, in Togoku (eastern Japan) and Kyushu where zaichi ryoshu (local proprietors) became similar to traditional headmen, and there were many hyakushomyo and myoden, many Zaikeyaku were levied.

Particularly, in Togoku (eastern Japan) and Kyushu where zaichi ryoshu (local proprietors) became similar to Nanushi (village headmen) and Hyakusho-myo (smaller holdings of shoen held by ordinary peasants) were not established, many Zaikeyaku were levied.

sen.j: 在家を下人・所従と同様の従属民とする見方もあるが、在家の位置づけは地域によって異なっている上に、実際に領主の人格的支配が在家にまで及んでいたとする記録はない。
sen.e: Zaike could be categorized as slave similar to genin (the base) and shoju (followers); but, zaike was considered to be different for each region, and besides, there was no record indicating that ryoshu controlled over zaike in fact.

sen.j: 検注によって在家が確定され、均等賦課を原則としていたが、検注帳に固定された在家を本在家、新たに在家したものを脇在家・新在家と称した。
sen.e: Zaike was confirmed through kenden (land servey) and taxes were equally assessed in principle; zaike fixed to the kenchucho is called Honzaike (main zaike), and newly added as zaike was called wakizaike or shinzaike.
